description: Learned borrowing from Latin obliterātus, oblitterātus (“having been blotted out, effaced, erased; having been forgotten”) + English -ate (suffix meaning ‘to act in [the specified manner]’ forming verbs, and ‘characterized by [the specified thing]’ forming adjectives). Obliterātus and oblitterātus are respectively the perfect passive participles of obliterō and oblitterō (“to blot out, efface, erase, obliterate; to cause to be forgotten”), probably either:

adjectives.description: obliterate (comparative more obliterate, superlative most obliterate) (obsolete)

entries.meaning: (except poetic) Completely destroyed or erased; effaced, obliterated.
(entomology, rare) Of markings on an insect: difficult to distinguish from the background; faint, indistinct.

verbs.description: obliterate (third-person singular simple present obliterates, present participle obliterating, simple past and past participle obliterated)

entries.meaning: To destroy (someone or something) completely, leaving no trace; to annihilate, to wipe out.
examples: Synonyms: bedash, do away with, eradicate, extirpate, raze, uproot; see also Thesaurus:destroy

entries.meaning: To hide (something) by covering it; to conceal, to obscure.
examples: The rainclouds oblierated the sun as they swept across the sky.

entries.meaning: (also figuratively) To make (a drawing, text which is printed or written, etc.) indecipherable, either by erasing or obscuring it; to blot out, to efface, to delete.
(biology, pathology, chiefly passive) To close up or fill (a body cavity, vessel, etc.) with tissue.
(philately) To cancel (a postage stamp) with a postmark so it cannot be reused.
To destroy completely, leaving no trace.
(biology, pathology) Of a body cavity, vessel, etc.: to close up or fill with tissue.
